title: Treat failure to commit to database as a fatal error
body:
### Description
When the database is unable to commit transactions, treat it as a fatal error and exit teku.  This allows monitoring to restart the service or node to recover from the issue.

This includes cases where the underlying disk fails, out of space errors and database corruption.

- maybe a tolerance, like N failures (5-10?)

i've got no idea how much a retry would complicate things or if there are any cases where it would help, in the example above or in case of disk full which apparently would trigger something like this, it doesn't seem like it would help. the above log went on for hours, a restart of teku sorted it

I think all the `DatabaseException` cases I've seen have been pretty fatal, but it's a pretty generic type of exception so won't always be.  There's actually a status field in `RocksDbException` which can be set to things like `tryAgain` which probably shouldn't be considered fatal. This example would come up as an `IoError` which would be fatal.

Given there's such a clear status in the underlying exception I think we can just add a simple flag to say if it's fatal or not and go from there.
